unnormalised: Delhi Chokes: Air Quality Plummets to 'Severe' Levels
normalised: Delhi Chokes: Air Quality Plummets to 'Severe' Levels

unnormalised: New Delhi, November 8, 2024 – Air quality in the National Capital Territory has deteriorated sharply, reaching "severe" levels according to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). The Air Quality Index (AQI) soared past 450 in several areas, including Anand Vihar and RK Puram, prompting health advisories from AIIMS.
normalised: New Delhi, eighth November two thousand and twenty four – Air quality in the National Capital Territory has deteriorated sharply, reaching "severe" levels according to the Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B). The Air Quality Index (A Q I) soared past four hundred and fifty in several areas, including Anand Vihar and R K Puram, prompting health advisories from A I I M S.

unnormalised: Experts attribute the spike to a combination of factors, including stubble burning in neighboring states like Haryana and Punjab, vehicular emissions, and unfavorable meteorological conditions. The CPCB has urged residents, particularly children and the elderly, to limit outdoor activities.
normalised: Experts attribute the spike to a combination of factors, including stubble burning in neighboring states like Haryana and Punjab, vehicular emissions, and unfavorable meteorological conditions. The C P C B has urged residents, particularly children and the elderly, to limit outdoor activities.

unnormalised: The worsening air quality brings back memories of the smog-filled scenes from the Bollywood film "Delhi 6", albeit on a larger scale. The Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) has been implemented, including restrictions on construction and the deployment of water sprinklers to settle dust particles. The government has allocated Rs. 200 crores for initiatives aimed at curbing pollution, focusing on incentivizing cleaner transportation and promoting eco-friendly farming practices within a 300 km radius of Delhi.
normalised: The worsening air quality brings back memories of the smog-filled scenes from the Bollywood film "Delhi six", albeit on a larger scale. The Graded Response Action Plan (G R A P) has been implemented, including restrictions on construction and the deployment of water sprinklers to settle dust particles. The government has allocated rupee two hundred crores for initiatives aimed at curbing pollution, focusing on incentivizing cleaner transportation and promoting eco-friendly farming practices within a three hundred kilometer radius of Delhi.
